Award.AwardTitle: Developing FTIR microscopy for lithic residue analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Archaeology provides one of the best means of studying the ability of human societies to respond to climatic and environmental change. Throughout the course of human evolution, stone tools have been the primary medium by which humans have interacted with the environment through the modification of natural resources for food, shelter, clothing, and other material needs. Therefore, stone tools in archaeological sites represent one of the most important data sets for reconstructing prehistoric human adaptations. Yet one of archaeologists' greatest challenges remains the rigorous interpretation of stone tool functions. Currently, one of the ways this is done is through the identification of microscopic remains of materials worked by stone tools (e.g., plant and animal tissue), which are sometimes preserved on tool surfaces. Existing methods of microscopic residue analysis, however, are either destructive or produce ambiguous results. Newer, non-destructive, replicable methods based upon analytical chemistry are available, but need to be developed. This project will develop Fourier-Transform Infrared (FTIR) microscopy as a new method of residue analysis. It will have three major impacts. First, application of this method will provide a more direct means of inferring past human activities than the current ambiguous approaches. Second, the development of FTIR microscopy for residue analysis will provide a non-destructive means of identifying not only residues, but the composition of most archaeological materials, such as paints, pigments, textiles, food residues, ceramics, and the like. This has crucial implications for the conservation of the non-renewable archaeological record of the United States, the cultural patrimony of the United States. It also has important implications for heritage studies at home and abroad, as indigenous groups are increasingly wary about the destruction of cultural artifacts. The development of non-destructive, non-invasive methods such as this one will be a boon to researchers working with ethnographic and prehistoric materials of all kinds. Third, this project will train graduate and undergraduate students (many of whom are women, including ethnic minorities) in cutting-edge scientific methods, providing skills applicable to a wide range of jobs.

The aim of this project is to create a library of experimental reference samples of FTIR reflectance spectra that will be standards against which archaeological spectra can be compared. The standards will include some of the most common residues on stone tools, such as animal muscle, fat, skin, bone, and hair; bird feathers; fish scales; plant fibers, wood, resin, ochre, and manganese. These residues will be generated experimentally on a variety of stone surfaces, from which reflectance spectra will then be obtained using FTIR microscopy. In addition, experimental pieces will be placed in a simulated burial environment for one year, to generate standards on residues altered by burial. In addition to publishing the results in peer-reviewed journals, all of the standards will be made available to the research community, in perpetuity, on open-source websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing FTIR microscopy for lithic residue analysis

Throughout the course of human evolution, stone tools have been the primary medium by which humans have interacted with the environment through the modification of natural resources for food, shelter, clothing, and so forth.  Therefore, stone tools in archaeological sites represent one of the most important data sets for reconstructing prehistoric human adaptations.  Reconstructing human adaptations and lifeways requires understanding how stone tools were used, which has been challenging to infer. Currently, one of the ways this is done is through the identification of microscopic residues of materials worked by stone tools (e.g., plant and animal tissue), which are sometimes preserved on the tool surfaces.  Existing methods of microscopic residue analysis, however, have produced ambiguous results.

The intellectual merit of the project is evident in its design and its results. In order to address the problem noted above, the purpose of the project has been to introduce a new method of lithic residue analysis that is rigorous, replicable, and objective. It is based upon obtaining not only visual, but chemical information from residues using Fourier-Transform Infrared (FTIR) microscopy. Developing this new technique, which was the goal of the project, required 1) demonstrating that reflectance FTIR spectra are equivalent to transmittance FTIR spectra; 2) investigating the effects of the stone and residue morphology on reflectance FTIR spectra; 3) developing a library of FTIR standards of residue types; and 4) studying how residues change with burial. All four aims of the project were accomplished, and a library of standards has now been published and is freely available on-line. The standards include the most common residues on stone tools, such as animal muscle, fat, skin, bone, and hair; bird feathers; fish scales; plant fibers, wood, resin, ochre, and manganese. They are also published thoroughly in two publications in peer-reviewed journals:

G. Monnier, E. Frahm, B. Luo, K. Missal, 2018.  Developing FTIR microspectroscopy for the analysis of animal-tissue residues on stone tools.  Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory 25:1-44.  

G. Monnier, E. Frahm, B. Luo, K. Missal, 2017.  Developing FTIR microspectroscopy for analysis of plant residues on stone tools.  Journal of Archaeological Science 78:158-178. 

The results pertaining to the fourth aim, the degradation of residues with burial, will be submitted for publication within 2018.

The broader impacts of the project are significant. The successful development of this method means that we now have a new, non-destructive tool for inferring past human activities from stone tools, which are the most common artifact for 99% of human history.  Additionally, this new tool can be applied not only to stone artifacts, but also to the study of other archaeological materials, such as paints, pigments, textiles, food residues, ceramics, and the like.  This has crucial implications for the conservation of the archaeological record, which is non-renewable, in the United States and elsewhere.  It also has important applications within heritage studies at home and abroad, as the world is becoming increasingly wary about the destruction of indigenous cultural artifacts.  The development of non-destructive, non-invasive methods such as this one will be a boon to researchers working with ethnographic and prehistoric materials of all kinds.  Finally, this project has provided extensive training and experience in cutting-edge scientific methods within vibrational spectroscopy, optical microscopy, electron microscopy, and laboratory techniques to six individuals. These individuals, including one postdoctoral fellow, three graduate students (two female), and two undergraduate students (both female, one a minority), have used their skills in research and to acquire new jobs in scientific fields.
